questions.question: Question 1: What is the host in which a parasite passes through its sexual stages of maturity called?
questions.explanation:
A host in which a parasite passes through its sexual stage of maturity is called the definitive host 
or primary host. A host in which a parasite exists in the larval or asexual form is called an intermediate host or 
secondary host. A host which acts as the only source of development for a parasite is called the obligate host. Note: A host in which the organism remains alive but no development occurs is called a transport 
host.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 2: For which of the following diseases is man the dead-end host?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, man is the dead-end host for tetanus and rabies. A dead-end host is a host from which the infectious agent lacks a portal of exit to continue its 
propagation. Humans are dead-end hosts for : 127 
Sold by @itachibot • Rabies • Tetanus • Bubonic Plague • Trichinosis
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 3: While studying a disease, you find that it affects both humans and lower vertebrates and can 
be transmitted in either direction. How would you classify this disease?
questions.explanation:
A disease that affects both humans and lower vertebrates and which can be transmitted in either 
direction is classified as amphixenosis. E.g, Trypanosoma cruzi and Schistosoma japonicum. It is a type of zoonoses. Zoonoses are diseases that are transmitted between vertebrate animals 
and humans. Other types of zoonoses include: • Anthropozoonoses - infections that are transmitted to man from vertebrates. E.g., Rabies, plague 
etc. • Zooanthroponoses - infections that are transmitted to vertebrates from humans. E.g., Human 
tuberculosis in cattle. Epizootic disease refers to an outbreak or epidemic of a disease in an animal population, often 
with the implication that it may also affect human populations. Enzootic disease is an endemic 
occurring in animals. Note: Epornithic diseases are those diseases which are epidemic in bird populations. E.g., 
Psittacosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 4: What is a disease imported to an area from another called?
questions.explanation:
Exotic diseases are those imported into a country where they do not occur usually. E.g, rabies in 
the United Kingdom. Enzootic diseases are those which are endemic in animals. E.g, anthrax, brucellosis. Epornithic disease refers to an epidemic in birds. E.g, psittacosis. Epizootic disease refers to an outbreak of a disease or an epidemic in animals with the implication 
that it may affect humans. E.g, Q fever, influenza.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following best describes a disease that has a haphazard occurrence?
questions.explanation:
Sporadic diseases occur in a haphazard and irregular manner from time to time. Endemic refers to the constant presence and /or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent 
in a population within a geographic area. 128 
Sold by @itachibot Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of a disease above what is 
normally expected in that population in that area. Pandemic is an epidemic occurring over a wide area, crossing international boundaries, and 
usually affecting a large number of people. Note: Opportunistic infections are those that occur in the presence of immune suppression or 
deficiency like cytomegalovirus.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 6: In a community, there are usually 40-50 reported cases of dengue every week. This week, 
there were 48 reported cases. This would classify as:
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease. Endemic diseases are those that have a constant presence and /or usual prevalence of a disease or 
infectious agent in a population within a geographic area. Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of a disease above what is 
normally expected in that population in that area. Outbreak carries the same definition of an epidemic, but is often used for a more limited 
geographic area. Sporadic diseases occur in a haphazard and irregular manner from time to time.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 7: The following are the disease frequencies in a population. Based on the number of cases 
which of the following is the correct match?
questions.explanation:
Disease 1- the cases have been almost the same so it has to be endemic. Disease 2- there is an alarming increase in the number of cases. It has to be an epidemic. Disease 3- the number of cases has decreased without any explanation so it has to be sporadic. Epidemic refers to the occurrence of a disease in excess of expected frequency. A pandemic is an epidemic affecting a large population over a large geographical area crossing 
international boundaries. An endemic disease is a regularly occurring disease in a population in expected frequency without 
any importation from outside. Sporadic diseases present as scattered cases of infection without relation temporally/spatially.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 8: Surveillance data of an endemic disease reveals that most of the children in the area had been 
affected and had to be hospitalised. However, most of the adults remained asymptomatic 124 
Sold by @itachibot carriers. Which category does this disease belong to?
questions.explanation:
The disease in question belongs to the category of holoendemic diseases. In such diseases, a 
higher prevalence and pathogenic response are seen among the children in an area. The adults 
tend to be either asymptomatic carriers or show reduced damage by the disease process. E.g, 
malaria. 129 
Sold by @itachibot An endemic disease is a disease that is present constantly in a population or in a given area 
without importation from outside. E.g, kala-azar in Bihar. A hyperendemic disease is a disease that is constantly present at high incidence and prevalence 
among all groups in a population. E.g, dengue in India. A syndemic is the aggregation of two or more concurrent or sequential epidemics or disease 
clusters in a population with biological interactions, which exacerbate the prognosis and burden 
of disease. It is also known as a synergistic epidemic. Note: Quasiendemic is not a term used in infectious disease epidemiology.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 9: In which of the following diseases is subclinical infection not seen?
questions.explanation:
Subclinical infection is not seen in measles. It always causes the development of overt signs and 
symptoms. Subclinical infection refers to an inapparent, covert, missed or abortive case. The host harbours 
and sheds the infectious agent but does not develop signs and symptoms of the disease. Subclinical infections are seen in diseases like: • Hepatitis A • Diphtheria • Japanese encephalitis • Rubella Subclinical infections can only be detected by laboratory tests. They frequently occur during a 
person’s lifetime and are responsible for the immunity shown by humans to a variety of 
disease-producing microbes. Note: Subclinical cases should be differentiated from latent infections. In a latent infection, the 
host does not shed the organism but it lies dormant without signs and symptoms.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 10: In which of the following states will the host not shed the infectious organism?
questions.explanation:
The host does not shed the infectious organism in case of a latent infection. This is defined as a 
state in which the host does not show signs and symptoms of the disease and does not shed the 
organism. It can be seen in conditions like herpes simplex, ancylostomiasis, infections due to slow viruses, 
Brill-Zinsser disease, etc. Subclinical infection is a state where the host harbours the infectious agent without developing 
signs and symptoms but sheds the infectious agent. This state is seen in conditions like hepatitis 
A, rubella, mumps, etc. Healthy carriers are those who had subclinical infections and later developed a carrier state 
without suffering from the overt disease. This state is seen in: (mnemonic: CM - DPT) 130 
Sold by @itachibot • Cholera • Meningitis • Diphtheria • Polio • Typhoid Convalescent carriers are those which shed the infectious agent during the convalescent 
phase/recovery phase. Such carriers are seen in diphtheria, typhoid, cholera, pertussis, etc.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 11: While in a health camp, you notice a child with fever and rash. On subsequent history, you 
find out that similar symptoms occurred in her friend 6 days back. How will you 
epidemiologically categorise the child you examined?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the child is categorised as the index case. It is the first case that comes to 
the notice of an investigator or physician. The primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit. A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case. A suspect case refers to a patient who has all the features of the disease but has not been 
diagnosed with it yet. Note: There is no such term as tertiary case.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 12: 125 
Sold by @itachibot You are part of a research programme for COVID-19 and are asked to define the median 
incubation period. How will you define it?

options.a: Interval between onset of symptoms in primary and secondary cases
options.b: Time required for 50% of cases to occur following exposure
options.c: Interval between exposure and the occurrence of the first symptom
options.d: Time required for the start of pathogenesis following exposure

questions.explanation:
The median incubation period is the time required for 50% of the cases to occur following 
exposure. The median incubation period of COVID-19 of approximately 5 days. Incubation period is the time interval between invasion of the infectious agent and the appearance 
of the first symptom or sign in the body. It is termed as the latent period in non-infectious 
diseases. Incubation period depends upon: • Generation time of pathogen • Portal of entry • Infective dose • Individual susceptibility Incubation period is useful for : • Tracing the source of infection and contacts. • Determining the period of surveillance or quarantine. • Planning immunization. • Identification of point source or propagated epidemics. • Determining the prognosis. 131 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question:
Question 13: In a school of 100 children, a child developed measles. Four days later, 3 of her classmates 
developed measles. What do these intervening four days correspond to?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the first child is the primary case and her classmates are the secondary 
cases. Hence, the interval between them developing the disease i.e., the intervening four days, is 
called the serial interval. The time interval between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called serial 
interval. By collecting information about a whole series of such disease onsets, the distribution of the 
secondary cases can be made. From this information, an approximation of the incubation period 
can be done. Lead time/lead interval refers to the period between the first possible time of detection and the 
usual time of diagnosis. Incubatory interval/ incubation period refers to the time period between invasion of a pathogen to 
appearance of the first sign or symptom. Latent interval/ latent period refers to the period between disease initiation to detection of 
the disease. It is usually used for non-infectious diseases and is equivalent to the incubation 
period. Note : • Primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit. • Secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case. • Index case is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 14: The time interval between which of the following is called generation time?

options.a: Development of primary case and secondary case
options.b: Receipt of infection by host and maximum infectivity of the same host
options.c: Infection and first sign or symptom
options.d: Infection and initiation of pathogenesis inside the host

questions.explanation:
Generation time is the time interval between receipt of infectious agent by the host and the point 
of maximum infectivity of the same host.
questions.chapter_heading: Basic Definitions in Infectious Disease Epidemi

questions.question: Question 15: For which of the following diseases is soil not a reservoir?
questions.explanation:
The main reservoir of the coccobacilli belonging to the genus Brucella that cause brucellosis are 
animals like sheep, cattle, horses, goats, whales, and dogs. A reservoir is the environment (e.g. soil, humans, animals, water, etc.) where the infectious agent 
grows and multiplies (natural habitat) and from where it can be transmitted to a susceptible host. A source is an animal, object, human or substance which acts as an immediate mode 
of transmission and may or may not be a part of the reservoir. Option A: Coccidiomycosis is also called Valley fever and the causative fungi belong to the 
Coccidiodes. The main reservoir of this organism is soil. 132 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Bacillus anthracis is a soil commensal and is also found on the hides and dried skins of 
infected animals. Option C: The natural reservoir for the fungi causing mycetoma is soil. 133 
Sold by @itachibot Dynamics of Disease Transmission
